STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 02, 2022
Maureen Clore
Antrim/Charlevoix/Emmet County DHHS
2229 Summit Park Drive
Petoskey, MI 49770
RE: License #: CP240201034
Antrim/Charlevoix/Emmet County DHHS
2229 Summit Park Drive
Petoskey, MI 49770
Dear Ms. Clore:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
July 25, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Kari Muntean, Area Manager, at 734-395-0920.
Sincerely,
Doug Turrill, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 11
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI 49684
(734) 395-0920
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP240201034
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services

Lansing, MI 48902

Demetrius Starling, Designee

Petoskey, MI 49770

SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to
a youth before placement in independent living.
One of one independent living files was reviewed. The file did not document that the
youth received a copy of the program statement before placement.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living
with a copy of the agency's policies and procedures
required by this rule.
One of one independent living files was reviewed. The file did not document that the
youth received a copy of the agency’s policies and procedures.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between
the youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
One of one independent living files was reviewed. The file did not contain a mutually
agreed upon contract between the youth and the agency.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans/PATP
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line supervisor, when
4

siblings in care are placed apart. • Parents who are a
member of a participating household. • Youth ages 14 and
older. • Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
courtordered caregivers.
Two of six foster care files reviewed documented either that the parent received the
PATP’s beyond 30 days or did not receive the PATP. In one file the USP was due
May 17, 2022, and the PATP was emailed to the parent on July 19, 2022. The file
contained a second USP that was due February 16, 2022, and that PATP was
emailed to the parent on May 9, 2022. The file contained a third USP that was due
on November 18, 2021, and was emailed to the parent on July 19, 2022.
A second file contained a USP that was due April 14, 2022, and there were no
parental signatures indicating that the parent received the PATP.
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts – Timely Entry
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face
contacts listed below in MISACWIS within five business
days of the contact. This includes attempted and missed
face-to-face contacts.
Two of six foster care files reviewed contained face to face contacts that were
entered into the MISACWIS system beyond the five working days as required by
policy. One file documented a contact on April 18, 2022, that was entered on May 3,
2022. The same file documented a contact on May 23, 2022, that was entered on
June 10, 2022. A second file documented a contact occurred on March 2, 2022, that
was entered on May 17, 2022.
Second Repeat Violation.
August 6, 2020, Renewal, CAP Approved August 16, 2020.
August 26, 2021, Interim, CAP Approved September 30, 2021
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts – Quality Visits
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have been
found to produce positive outcomes for children in foster
care. A quality visit is defined as one in which the
caseworker: • Can meet with each child individually,
without the presence of other individuals, to give the child
an opportunity to ask questions as well as discuss the
current placement. • Views the child's bedroom and
sleeping arrangements. • Verifies safe sleep environments
and practices for infants under 12 months. • Assesses each
child’s educational, medical, dental, mental health and
other needs and takes appropriate action or offers services
in response to the identified needs of each child. • Shows
5

interest in the child to build and establish rapport. • Shares
and explains the case plan, including the plan for parenting
time, visits with siblings and other relatives, and the child's
permanency plan, in a developmentally appropriate way
while allowing the child to ask questions and express
viewpoints.
One of six files reviewed did not contain documentation of quality visits on March 2,
2022, and June 22, 2022. Safety assessments and other relevant information
required by policy were not documented.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables: Updated Case Plan (USP) -
within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Three of six files reviewed either lacked documentation the FTM’s occurred during
USP case assessment or that the FTM occurred late, after the USP due date.
One file did not contain documentation that a FTM occurred for an USP due March
16, 2022. A second file did not contain documentation that FTM’s occurred for a
November 26, 2021, USP and a February 24, 2022, USP. A third file documented
that an FTM occurred on April 15, 2022, for a USP that was due April 14, 2022.
FOM 722-15 Case Closing – DHS-69 Action Summary
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary,
must be completed at the time of program closure; see
FOM 722-08E, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary.
One of two closed files reviewed did not contain an uploaded DHS-69 Action
Summary closing the case. The agency Program Manager submitted a completed
action summary for the case which was closed on January 21, 2022, however it was
not uploaded into MISACWIS at the time of the inspection.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Technical assistance was provided regarding youth with YAFC status who are placed
in an independent living placement. Discussion involved YAFC youth, when in an
independent living arrangement such as a college dorm or an apartment, then that
youth is considered to be in independent living and the independent living rules apply.
The independent living rules do not apply to YAFC youth living with a relative, in a
foster home or a CCI.
6

V. CONSULTATION
Consultation was not requested or provided at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
A corrective action plan, approved September 30, 2021, was submitted in response
to the Interim Inspection completed on August 26, 2021. There was one repeat
violation established during the current renewal Inspection regarding the timely
entering of face-to-face contacts into the MISACWIS system. The agency continues
to successfully address and correct rule and policy violations established during the
previous annual inspection.
Chief Administrators Annual Assessment: (CAA)
The CAA was reviewed and it was thorough in addressing violations and CAP
successes during the licensing period. The CAA clearly identified areas of needed
improvement as well as areas of success. The Chief Administrator noted that due to
limited office time for workers due to COVID restrictions and precautions that it has
been difficult to upload documents in a timely fashion. The Chief Administrator
further noted that a foster care staff vacancy as well as a staff person on medical
leave has presented challenges for the agency. The Chief Administrator reported
that the agency has also been assisting Grand Traverse/Kalkaska DHHS with direct
case coverage of foster care cases due to the lack of staff at that local office. These
situations have presented challenges to the agency which are successfully being
managed.
Interviews:
Staff interviewed reported feeling supported by their supervisors and the
administrative team. They also reported that their supervisors are knowledgeable
and readily available when they seek supervision. Staff further reported that they feel
that they are part of a supportive team and everyone works together. One staff
reported that assisting Grand Traverse/Kalkaska DHHS has created additional
challenges for the team.
Field Analyst Findings:
7

On June 1, 2022, the Field Analyst identified safety concerns in a foster home
involving unlocked bows and arrows as well as holes in a wall. A safety alert was
generated and a compliant filed on June 3, 2022. The agency initiated special
evaluation #2022C0630937 which addressed the concerns. The safety concerns
have since been rectified.
During the entrance conference the Field Analyst provided the agency with
information she had obtained during her visits to the homes. The Field Analyst
reported that foster parents and relatives feel supported by the agency and no
concerns were raised.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
July 29, 2022
________________________________________
Doug Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 1, 2022
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Area Manager
